member.name: T:Confluent.Kafka.vApus.IPC.EndPointManagerServiceConnectionException
member.summary: Thrown when could not connect to the epms via EndPointManagerServiceConnection.GetClient();

member.name: M:Confluent.Kafka.vApus.IPC.EndPointManagerServiceConnectionException.#ctor(System.String)
member.summary: Thrown when could not connect to the epms via EndPointManagerServiceConnection.GetClient();

member.name: P:Confluent.Kafka.vApus.IPC.MessageEventArgs.Message
member.summary: The sent or received message.

member.name: P:Confluent.Kafka.vApus.IPC.MessageEventArgs.RemoteEndPoints
member.summary: The local end points of the receivers. Only filled in for Sender events: before message sent - all registred receivers; After message sent - Alle responding receivers.

summary.para: Add a new Receiver in the code of the process you want to receive messages. Make sure the handles matches the one of the Sender.
The handle is a value shared by a Sender and its Receivers.
It links both parties so messages from a Sender get to the right Receivers.
Make sure this is a unique value: use a GUID for instance:
There is absolutely no checking to see if this handle is used in another Sender - Receivers relation.

member.name: P:Confluent.Kafka.vApus.IPC.Receiver.LocalEndPoint
member.summary: The end point this receiver is listening on.

summary.para: This is an optional parameter in the constructor.
If you don't use it, receiver end points are stored in the Windows registry and IPC communication is only possible for processes running under the current local user.

If you do use it, these end points are fetched from a Windows service over tcp, making it a distributed IPC.This however will be slower and implies a security risk since there will be network traffic.
Receives messages of a Sender having the same handle.
When using the end point manager service, some security measures are advised.
You can use Shared.Encrypt(...) (and Shared.Decrypt(...)) to encrypt your received messages (if they are strings) via the MessageReceived event.
Alternatively you can use a ssh tunnel, that will probably be safer and faster

param.name: handle
param.para: The handle is a value shared by a Sender and its Receivers. ; , * + and - cannot be used!
It links both parties so messages from a Sender get to the right Receivers.
Make sure this is a unique value: use a GUID for instance:
There is absolutely no checking to see if this handle is used in another Sender - Receivers relation.

param.name: ipAddressToRegister
param.para: This parameter is only useful if you are using an end point manager service.
A receiver listens to all available IPs for connections. The ip that is registered on the end point manager (service) is by default automatically determined.
However, this does not take into account that senders, receiver or end point manager services are possibly not on the same network.
Therefor you can override this behaviour by supplying your own IP that will be registered to the end point manager service.

param.name: allowedPorts
param.para: This parameter is only useful if you are using an end point manager service.
To make firewall settings easier, you can specify a pool of TCP ports where the receiver can choose one from to listen on. If none of these ports are available, this will fail.
If you don't use this parameter, one of the total available ports on the system will be chosen.

param.name: endPointManagerServiceConnection
param.para: This is an optional parameter.
If you don't use it, receiver end points are stored in the Windows registry and IPC communication is only possible for processes running under the current local user.

If you do use it, these end points are fetched from a Windows service over tcp, making it a distributed IPC.This however will be slower and implies a security risk since there will be network traffic.

summary.para: Reads handle size, handle, 1 if message is byte array or 0, message size and message from the stream.
If the handle in the message is invalid the connection will be closed.
Add a new Sender in the code of the process you want to send messages. Make sure the handles matches the one of the Receivers.
Suscribe to OnSendFailed for error handeling. Please note: Sending will always fail when a Receiver disappears.

member.name: F:Confluent.Kafka.vApus.IPC.Sender._hashcode
member.summary: Hashcode of the message. When resending the same data it is not serialized again.

summary.para: When true, a message (+ encapsulation) you send is kept in memory. When you resend the same message it will not be serialized again.
This is an optional parameter in the constructor.
If you don't use it, receiver end points are stored in the Windows registry and IPC communication is only possible for processes running under the current local user.

If you do use it, these end points are fetched from a Windows service over tcp, making it a distributed IPC.This however will be slower and implies a security risk since there will be network traffic.
Add a new Sender in the code of the process you want to send messages. Make sure the handles matches the one of the Receivers.
When using the end point manager service, some security measures are advised.
You can use Shared.Encrypt(...) (and Shared.Decrypt(...)) to encrypt messages (if they are strings) before sending them.
Alternatively you can use a ssh tunnel, that will probably be safer and faster
Suscribe to OnSendFailed for error handeling. Please note: Sending will always fail when a Receiver disappears.

param.name: handle
param.para: The handle is a value shared by a Sender and its Receivers. ; , * + and - cannot be used!
It links both parties so messages from a Sender get to the right Receivers.
Make sure this is a unique value: use a GUID for instance:
There is absolutely no checking to see if this handle is used in another Sender - Receivers relation.

param.name: endPointManagerServiceConnection
param.para: This is an optional parameter.
If you don't use it, receiver end points are stored in the Windows registry and IPC communication is only possible for processes running under the current local user.

If you do use it, these end points are fetched from a Windows service over tcp, making it a distributed IPC.This however will be slower and implies a security risk since there will be network traffic.

param.name: buffered
param.para: When true, a message (+ encapsulation) you send is kept in memory. When you resend the same message it will not be serialized again.
This buffer can ony hold one message. Using this will make sending messages faster and will take up more memory. Use this wisely for large messages.

member.name: M:Confluent.Kafka.vApus.IPC.Sender.Send(System.Object)
member.summary: Send a message to the Receivers. This is (partly) a blocking function.
member.param: If the given object is a byte array, it will not be serialized. Otherwise, the object will be serialized using a binary formatter.

member.name: M:Confluent.Kafka.vApus.IPC.Sender.SerializeMessage(System.Object)
member.summary: Writes the handle size, the handle (UTF8 encoding), 1 if message is byte array or 0, the message size and the message to an array.

member.name: M:Confluent.Kafka.vApus.IPC.Sender.SetTcpSenders
member.summary: Clean up the stored tcp clients (_senders) and add new ones if need be.

member.name: T:Confluent.Kafka.vApus.IPC.EndPointManager
member.summary: Stores end points (handles and tcp ports) in the Windows Registry for the current user or in an end point manager service for the IPC message receivers.

member.name: F:Confluent.Kafka.vApus.IPC.EndPointManager.WINDOWS_REGISTRY_KEY
member.summary: Used for a key in the Windows Registry (current user, volatile) to store the end points when not using an end point manager service.

member.name: M:Confluent.Kafka.vApus.IPC.EndPointManager.RegisterReceiver(System.String,System.Net.IPAddress,System.Int32[],Confluent.Kafka.vApus.IPC.EndPointManagerServiceConnection)
member.summary: Add a new tcp port to the endpoints for a receiver.

param.name: handle
param.para: The handle is a value shared by a Sender and its Receivers. ; , * + and - cannot be used!
It links both parties so messages from a Sender get to the right Receivers.
Make sure this is a unique value: use a GUID for instance:
There is absolutely no checking to see if this handle is used in another Sender - Receivers relation.

param.name: ipAddressToRegister
param.para: This parameter is only useful if you are using an end point manager service.
A receiver listens to all available IPs for connections. The ip that is registered on the end point manager (service) is by default automatically determined.
However, this does not take into account that senders, receiver or end point manager services are possibly not on the same network.
Therefor you can override this behaviour by supplying your own IP that will be registered to the end point manager service.

param.name: allowedPorts
param.para: This parameter is only useful if you are using an end point manager service.
To make firewall settings easier, you can specify a pool of TCP ports where the receiver can choose one from to listen on. If none of these ports are available, this will fail.
If you don't use this parameter, one of the total available ports on the system will be chosen.

param.name: endPointManagerServiceConnection
param.para: This is an optional parameter.
If you don't use it, receiver end points are stored in the Windows registry and IPC communication is only possible for processes running under the current local user.

If you do use it, these end points are fetched from a Windows service over tcp, making it a distributed IPC.This however will be slower and implies a security risk since there will be network traffic.

member.summary: The sender must use this to be able to send data to the correct receivers.

It links both parties so messages from a Sender get to the right Receivers.
Make sure this is a unique value: use a GUID for instance:

member.name: M:Confluent.Kafka.vApus.IPC.EndPointManager.CleanupEndPoints(System.Collections.Generic.Dictionary{System.String,System.Collections.Generic.Dictionary{System.String,System.Collections.Generic.HashSet{System.Int32}}},System.Boolean)
member.summary: Only used for local IPC. When using the end point manager service, this service handles the cleaning.
member.param: All end points that are not used anymore are filtered out.
Register the cleaned end point is applicable.

member.name: M:Confluent.Kafka.vApus.IPC.EndPointManager.SetRegisteredEndPoints(System.Collections.Generic.Dictionary{System.String,System.Collections.Generic.Dictionary{System.String,System.Collections.Generic.HashSet{System.Int32}}},Confluent.Kafka.vApus.IPC.EndPointManagerServiceConnection)
member.summary: Set endpoints to the Windows Registry (current user, volatile) or the end point manager service, if any.

member.name: M:Confluent.Kafka.vApus.IPC.EndPointManager.SetRegisteredEndPoints(System.String)
member.summary: Set endpoints to the Windows Registry (current user, volatile).

member.name: M:Confluent.Kafka.vApus.IPC.EndPointManager.GetUsedTcpPorts
member.summary: Only take used tcp ports into accounts. What's been registered in the registry or the epm service does not matter.

member.name: P:Confluent.Kafka.vApus.IPC.EndPointManagerServiceConnection.EndPointManagerServiceEP
member.summary: End point info to connect to the service over tcp.

member.name: P:Confluent.Kafka.vApus.IPC.EndPointManagerServiceConnection.Password
member.summary: [optional] Password for Rijndael encryption for communication with the epm service. Alternatively you can use an ssh tunnel, that will probably be safer and faster.

member.name: P:Confluent.Kafka.vApus.IPC.EndPointManagerServiceConnection.Salt
member.summary: [optional] Salt for Rijndael encryption for communication with the epm service. Example (don't use this): new byte[] { 0x59, 0x06, 0x59, 0x3e, 0x21, 0x4e, 0x55, 0x34, 0x96, 0x15, 0x11, 0x13, 0x72 }

member.name: M:Confluent.Kafka.vApus.IPC.EndPointManagerServiceConnection.#ctor(System.Net.IPEndPoint)
member.param: End point info to connect to the service over tcp.

member.name: M:Confluent.Kafka.vApus.IPC.EndPointManagerServiceConnection.#ctor(System.Net.IPEndPoint,System.String,System.Byte[])
member.param: End point info to connect to the service over tcp.
Password for Rijndael encryption for communication with the epm service. Alternatively you can use an ssh tunnel, that will probably be safer and faster.
Salt for Rijndael encryption for communication with the epm service. Example (don't use this): new byte[] { 0x59, 0x06, 0x59, 0x3e, 0x21, 0x4e, 0x55, 0x34, 0x96, 0x15, 0x11, 0x13, 0x72 }

member.summary: Get the endpoints from the endpoint manager service.
member.param: Empty string to get the end points or the end point represeted as a string to set them.

member.summary: Shared functions for internal and external use.

member.summary: Default port for the epms service to listen on.

member.name: F:Confluent.Kafka.vApus.IPC.Shared.LONGSIZE
member.summary: The amount of memory, in bytes, a 64bit integer takes. (Should be obvious :))

member.name: M:Confluent.Kafka.vApus.IPC.Shared.GetBytes(System.String)
member.summary: UTF8

member.name: M:Confluent.Kafka.vApus.IPC.Shared.GetString(System.Byte[])
member.summary: UTF8. '\0' gets automatically trimmed.

member.name: M:Confluent.Kafka.vApus.IPC.Shared.Ungzip(System.Byte[])
member.returns: '\0' at the end of the output is possible. Please take this into account.

member.name: M:Confluent.Kafka.vApus.IPC.Shared.ReadBytes(System.IO.Stream,System.Int32,System.Int64)
member.summary: Read bytes from a stream.
member.param: The amount of bytes read per go. This could be the receive buffer size of a socket.
The total amount of bytes that should be read.

member.name: M:Confluent.Kafka.vApus.IPC.Shared.WriteBytes(System.IO.Stream,System.Int32,System.Byte[])
member.summary: Write bytes to a stream.
member.param: The amount of bytes to write per go. This could be the send buffer size of a socket.

member.name: M:Confluent.Kafka.vApus.IPC.Shared.Encrypt(System.String,System.String,System.Byte[])
member.summary: A simple way to encrypt a string. (Rijndael, from utf8 to base 64) /// Example (don't use this password and salt): Encrypt("secret", "password", new byte[] { 0x59, 0x06, 0x59, 0x3e, 0x21, 0x4e, 0x55, 0x34, 0x96, 0x15, 0x11, 0x13, 0x72 });

member.name: M:Confluent.Kafka.vApus.IPC.Shared.Decrypt(System.String,System.String,System.Byte[])
member.summary: A simple way to decrypt a string. (Rijndael, from base 64 to utf8) Example (don't use this password and salt): Decrypt("****", "password", new byte[] { 0x59, 0x06, 0x59, 0x3e, 0x21, 0x4e, 0x55, 0x34, 0x96, 0x15, 0x11, 0x13, 0x72 });

member.name: M:Confluent.Kafka.vApus.IPC.Shared.GetIPs
member.summary: Return the v4 and the v6 IPs of the local machine (no loopbacks). Use this instead of Dns.GetHostEntry etc. These Dns fxs do not always work.
